Meta Embeds Manus AI, Coca-Cola Goes All-In, CMOs Are "Agentic With a Small A"

Today's top stories in AI + Product Marketing

1

Meta Embeds Manus AI Into Ads Manager

Meta is integrating its newly acquired AI agent tech directly into Ads Manager ‚Äî giving advertisers built-in automation for research, reporting, and campaign optimization. This is Meta showing it wants AI baked into the workflow, not bolted on.

Read on Search Engine Land ‚Üí
2

Coca-Cola Goes All-In on AI Marketing

With price-led growth slowing, Coke is leaning hard into AI to "refine persuasion at scale" ‚Äî using data to shape messages, target audiences, and adjust campaigns in near real-time. When the world's biggest brand pivots this visibly, it signals where the industry's headed.

Read on AI News ‚Üí
3

Crayon: AI + CI = 82% More Sales Effectiveness

New research shows companies using conversational intelligence tools alongside traditional competitive intel methods see 82% improvement in sales effectiveness. The key: getting market knowledge to the right people at the right time.

Read on DMNews ‚Üí
4

Digiday: CMOs Are "Agentic With a Small A"

Great reality-check piece. CMOs are adopting AI slower than the hype suggests ‚Äî focusing on automating campaign taxonomies, ad tracking, naming conventions, and "repetitive trafficking tasks" rather than full autonomy. The insight: AI adds clear value in the boring stuff first.

Read on Digiday ‚Üí
5

New Tool: "Layers" ‚Äî AI That Reads Your Codebase

Launched on Product Hunt yesterday. Connect your GitHub, and it analyzes what you built to auto-generate positioning, ICP, and a marketing action plan. Interesting approach: instead of asking PMMs to describe the product, just read the source code.

View on Product Hunt ‚Üí

üí° My Take

Read this one: The Digiday piece on CMOs being "agentic with a small a." The gap between AI capability and actual adoption is real ‚Äî and that's where the opportunity lives for PMM leaders who can bridge it. Most companies aren't ready for autonomous agents. They're ready for AI that handles the boring stuff well.
